conclusion: Extract the two straight-line equations from the graph.
Source line I passes through (I = 0 A, U = 3 V) and (I = 6 A, U = 0 V).
U = 3 V − 0.5 Ω · I, so the source has emf E = 3 V and internal resistance r = 0.5 Ω.
Resistor line II passes through the origin and the point (I = 2 A, U = 2 V).
U = (2 V / 2 A) I = 1 Ω · I, i.e. the resistor is R = 1 Ω.
Find the operating (intersection) point of the two lines.
Substituting back gives the terminal voltage U = 2 V.
Compute the power actually delivered by the source to the external circuit.
P_out = U I = 2 V × 2 A = 4 W.
The output power of the source is 4 W.
